displayed_text: Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When I’m laying down and going to sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And this is… Doctor: This is the sleeping pill, the Restoril. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright and these are your blood tests which you take over. Your calcium is good now so you can get… Patient: My calcium is good and I don’t have to take the big bills? Doctor: So it sounds like the big pills, you’re doing what I told you to. Doctor: Oh God.

Family Member: I brought juice. Doctor: Remember that? Doctor: I saw him last time. It was a whole lot of fun. A whole lot of fun. Doctor: How have the sugars been at home? Patient: They’ve been doing good. Doctor: Yeah? Good, good or mah good? Patient: Mah good. Doctor: Okay. Why is that? Because you’re (clears voice) Patient: Um, maybe a little of both. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But I, I, you know, I’m religious in checking my sugars. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Until the third of January or something. Doctor: You could wait until the third of January, or you could -- Patient: Now, if you got - You, you – I grabbed that number out of the air. You can – Doctor: You could try to wait or things like that. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, he could wait. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because, again, I like to wait a little bit. Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have some data that says says, um, people tolerate the chemo better once, uh, they have a little bit more space between getting the hormones and the chemo together. So Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let your body’s level of testosterone drop. Then, get the chemo, uh - that may be safer on your bone marrow than doing it all at once. Patient: That’s a done deal.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The other option again for lymph nodes of a specific size and the size limitation is more because one of the studies we have requires the smallest size of the lymph node to be one point five centimeter or higher. And that is uh a combination of a medication called Cabozantinib with an immune therapy. So that combination I think I would strongly recommend looking at if you have enough disease that needs treatment. Obviously if there’s… Patient: Are you gonna be able to find that out today? Doctor: I’m hoping to, yes. So that’s why I said let’s try and get some preliminary information on your CAT scans because that is going to be the key decision maker. Patient: More so than a bone? Doctor: I think the bone scan the problem is your report compared it to I don’t know a scan done years ago, because in between all the bone scans you had were here, they were not up there… Patient: Right. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So I think I cannot do a whole lot by the report, I do need to look at the actual scan which I will do right now. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ll tell you about both those things I’m hoping today before you leave. Patient: Before we leave.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Hum. Doctor: So but enough change that, that I think we’re probably not going in the- Patient: In the right direction. Doctor: In the right direction. So I think you know we didn’t get much response to the enzalutamide or that. It sounds, it seems like your cancer may just not be hormonally sensitive at this point. Patient: Okay. Doctor: To kind of go both ways, a low hormone, high hormone. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: Uh we often see after folks have been on what is also known as Zytiga- Patient: I was on it. Doctor: Yeah. We get, we get sort of resistance that carries through there. Patient: Ohh. Doctor: So that means uh we need to take you off. I mean the testosterone part of this, the input of the study was PSA going down. So you already, you have gone up a little. So you already hit that.

Patient: Yeah. Well, I, you know, I, I totally live, chemo would be logistically a problem. You know? I mean I’m, you know, I kind of dread it. I do. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I kind of knew it was coming but uh. What do you think the duration of that? Doctor: Of the treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So on a trial, it’s for eight treatments. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, you know, numb hands and feet, but in general the trial allows you to do that and then if you’re not on the vitamin C everybody starts to get the vitamin C.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Family Member: Okay. With what? Doctor: P-S-M-A. Family Member: Oh. P-S-M-A. Doctor: Which is, uh, antigen that a lot of the prostate cancers produce. So what it- what that treatment does, is it attaches to that antigen on the cancer cells and releases the radiation right where the cancer is at. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That is the idea behind it. For that, though, first, what we have to do is make sure that your cancer is actually expressing that antigen. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that is a specialized scan that is done either in Texas or in New York. Family Member: Yeah. We talked about that. Doctor: So you would have to go over there to get that scan before we can even decide if you should get the study or not. Family Member: So he’d have to have some blood work? Is it a blood draw? Is it, uh-? Doctor: For what?

Patient: Okay. Okay Doctor V____. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I’m I’m doing anything you want me to. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I’m good. Doctor: Okay so we’ll be back with all that paperwork and stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Do you want me to step out for a few? Doctor: I just uh, you can stay, I mean it doesn’t matter to me. I did realize I wasn’t quite done because I had gone back to get paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Alright well I’ll step out. Doctor: Yeah like give me like two minutes, we’ll be set. Okay (door closes) Patient: Okay. (Pause 30 seconds)

Patient: No. I don’t have any. Doctor: Still any numbness around your mouth or-? Patient: A little bit when, you know, coughing. Doctor: So. So how often are you taking the morphine? Patient: About two at night. Doctor: A little, nothing during the day? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your bowels been? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So slow? That’s what you told me last time. Patient: Yeah, but, you know. Doctor: Still moving daily?

Patient: I – yeah. Whatever. Doctor: I got a great idea! Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s do this! Family Member: I gotta get out. Doctor: Right. (Laughs) Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s get M__ to just talk hard, here’s what gotta do, thinkin’ movin’ forward. Patient: Who is M_? Doctor: M_ S_!!!! You know M_! She’s the research nurse! You’ve talked to her a thousand times already! Patient: Ohhhh. Family Member: She come back every day.

Patient: Yeah, it’s Rite Aid F___. Doctor: Two r’s or one r in F___? Patient: Two. No, it’s just one. Doctor: And do you know the zip for F___? Patient: No. Family Member: Umm, two oh five oh, maybe? (pause) Doctor: F___ five - one five two zero R____. Patient: That’s the one. R____ Doctor: You’ll take that for thirty days, and that will be sent there electronically, so you would be able to pick it up later today. Patient: Okay. Eh, any particular time of day? I’m sure it will come with, just as long as it is around the same time every day. Healthcare Professional: It just says “take it approximately, about the same time each day.” And you can take it with or without food. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that will just cause, uh, a little bit of soft stool.

Patient: Uh, you know, I am, uh, there, there was a few times whereas I felt like, uh, some pressure up here, and I just felt very lethargic, and, um, I took some, um, some aspirin- Doctor: Okay. Patient: Uh, or Tylenol, and that seemed to, you know, put me back in a normal state. Doctor: How are you doing just overall, just the anxiety, and sort of in the past you had some issues with that. Does that kind of seem like it’s controlled or-? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah. That’s, that’s more controlled. I think, you know, since, since I’ve been retired, I haven’t really had, other than flare-ups sometimes with my son, but for the most part, uh, you know, I’m pretty, you know, level minded. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Any new pain anywhere? Patient: No uh. Well, every once in a while, I get like a stiffness in my thighs. Doctor: Okay. When you’re doing something or just anytime? Patient: Every once in a while. Uh, it just, it just pops up. Doctor: And it’s in both thighs or one or-? Patient: Uh, sometimes it’s in both. Normally, it’s in both.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then you get randomized to the muscadine grape skin or placebo. And if you are on the placebo arm, if your PSA, if it's if the placebo is not working, then you get the muscadine grapeseed. Okay, so, eventually everybody on the trial can get the therapy. Okay? If you're not this genotype and you're not eligible because we don't think that you'll, you'd have any benefit. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But to see if you would be eligible for the study, you'd have to first join the study, then we do this genotype testing. And then if you're eligible, about 25% of the population is eligible. So you have a one in four shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if you're eligible, I think that that would actually be a reasonable option. Okay. The other trial is a trial of alaparib. This study is, a study of, it, so it's a PARP inhibitor. This medicine is used in breast cancer and ovarian cancer, and it's used sometimes in advanced prostate cancer, and we're studying to see if it can be used early on without hormone therapy in prostate cancer. Just to spare people from prostate cancer. The MAP study, the muscadine grape skin has very few side effects gas, upset stomach, this one can cause nausea and vomiting and can sometimes cause your blood counts to go lower. This is like an expensive medicine that is provided but usually you have to go through insurance for all the clinical trials. So this and this one, I'm not positive that you're eligible for yet either. Okay. So those are the two clinical trial options that we have for biochemical recurrence. Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: So what usually happens in general for clinical trials is that if you're interested in clinical trials, what I'll do is I'll contact the research nurse, and I'll say, you know, “Mr. H____ is interested in this clinical trial let's do it” because we have to make sure that your insurance allows you to be in clinical trials, and we have to confirm your eligibility and like for this, the MAP study- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month.

Patient: To get going? Doctor: A week or two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, it will take a week or two for you to meet up with him and then we’re off and running so soon. Patient: Okay and they do the scheduling? Doctor: Yeah then it’s all them. Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us.
